text_blocks.text: The air in the room tore open. It wasn't a portal; it was a glitch in reality. A silver sphere fell onto your desk with a heavy thud, cracking the surface.
The object hit your desk. It didn't bounce. High-density alloy. The seam lines were microscopicâ€”machining tolerances that don't exist in 2026. It smelled like ozone and burnt clutch plates.
The object fell like an omen from a Greek tragedy. It sat there, anachronistic and rude, interrupting your reading. It looked like something Da Vinci sketched but never had the titanium to build.
The shiny thing crashed your vibe. It was silver, sleek, and honestly? It looked better than the jewelry you wore to the Met Gala. It demanded attention.
You reached out to touch it. Bad idea.
Your instincts screamed 'biohazard,' but curiosity is a dangerous pathology. You reached out.
You've touched cursed idols and unexploded ordnance before. This didn't seem any worse. You reached out.
The metal didn't feel cold. It felt... hungry. It turned to liquid mercury the moment it touched your skin. It didn't clasp around your wrist; it sank IN.

Nano-assemblers. Millions of them. You watched in horror as the silver liquid dissolved into your epidermis, weaving itself into your nervous system. No pain, just a terrifying sense of connection. You are the hardware now.

It moved like living ink. The silver washed over your skin and disappeared beneath it, leaving a faint, glowing geometric tattoo that pulsed with your heartbeat. It felt less like technology and more like a pact.
You blinked. The world looked different. Text was floating in the air. A Retinal HUD.
System boot sequence initialized. Your vision was overlaid with telemetry data. Heart rate, ambient temperature, time dilation... it was an OS running directly on your optic nerve.
The world gained a new layer of paint. Golden lines traced the geometry of the room. You could see the structure of reality itself, overlaid with symbols you somehow understood.

A notification flared in your vision. A single ping from halfway across the world.

[SIGNAL DETECTED. PARTNER FOUND.]
